fields.summary: LDAP Sync:  group section expects LDAP/AD attribute to be FDN instead of attribute value; fails to look up and sync users

fields.description:
In the Eucalyptus 3.2 Admin Guide, under the [LDAP/AD Integration => Identity Mapping section|http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/3.2/ag/access_mapping_identities.html#access_mapping_identities], the explanation is a bit vague regarding relationship of _accounting-groups_, _groups-partition_, _groups_, and _users_ with each other.  Below is the explanation that helps convey the understanding needed to leverage the LDAP/AD mapping to IAM accounts.  We should determine how to best integrate this information, along with the information found in DOC-820, with the current documentation.  Any help needed with this update, please let me know.

*Updated Explanation* 

For the mapping exercise of having an account group called users with all the users with gidNubmer=100 inside the account group, the key here deals with the id-attribute and filter of each section:

* accounting-groups
* groups-partition
* groups
* users

Understanding object class types are really important here. More information about object class types, refer to the [LDAP Models RFC|http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4512.txt] under the "2.4.  Object Classes".  

*accounting-groups*

From looking at the LIC file parser, accounting-groups are more focused to ou, dc type objects.  So, for example, if you had the base _ou=Group,dc=net4,dc=lan_, and under that, you had the following sub-ou's:

* ou=Sales,ou=Group,dc=net4,dc=lan
* ou=Engineering,ou=Group,dc=net4,dc=lan

The ou for Sales/Engineering may look like the following:

{code}
dn: ou=Sales,ou=Group,dc=net4,dc=lan
objectClass: organizationalUnit
ou: Sales

dn: ou=Engineering,ou=Group,dc=net4,dc=lan
objectClass: organizationalUnit
ou: Engineering
{code}

Then you would set the id-attribute to _ou_, and _filter_ to _objectClass: organizationalunit_, to create an account for Engineering and Sales.  In short, accounting-groups is more focused on STRUCTURAL object classes.  For more information about this, refer to the [LDAP Models RFC|http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4512.txt].  Here is a brief section that explains this a bit more:

{code}
2.4.2.  Structural Object Classes

   As stated in [X.501]:

      An object class defined for use in the structural specification of
      the DIT is termed a structural object class.  Structural object
      classes are used in the definition of the structure of the names
      of the objects for compliant entries.

      An object or alias entry is characterized by precisely one
      structural object class superclass chain which has a single
      structural object class as the most subordinate object class.
      This structural object class is referred to as the structural
      object class of the entry.

      Structural object classes are related to associated entries:

        - an entry conforming to a structural object class shall
          represent the real-world object constrained by the object
          class;

        - DIT structure rules only refer to structural object classes;
          the structural object class of an entry is used to specify the
          position of the entry in the DIT;

        - the structural object class of an entry is used, along with an
          associated DIT content rule, to control the content of an
          entry.

      The structural object class of an entry shall not be changed.

   Each structural object class is a (direct or indirect) subclass of
   the 'top' abstract object class.
{code}

*groups-partition*

group-partitions are really powerful because you can pre-define account names, based upon "groups" that are present in LDAP/AD.  For example, with the example of the users with the gidNumber=100 in the same group called "users" - a groups-partition would possibly look like the following:

{code}
"groups-partition": {
          "accountgid100": ["users"],
}
{code}

This will then correlate the group "users", which will be discovered in the "groups" section of the LIC file, to the account "accountgid100".

*groups and users* 

groups and users are for more granular choosing of object class types. The key with these options is understanding what defines a group/user in LDAP/AD.  For example, here is a user and group:

{code}
dn: uid=user01,ou=people,dc=msjackson,dc=stankonia,dc=com
objectClass: top
objectClass: person
objectClass: organizationalPerson
objectClass: posixAccount
objectClass: shadowAccount
objectClass: inetOrgPerson
objectClass: inetLocalMailRecipient
uid: user01
cn: user 01
displayName: user 01
gecos: user 01
givenName: user
sn: 01
title: Test User 01
mail: user01@msjackson.stankonia.com
employeeNumber: 01
uidNumber: 4001
gidNumber: 4001
homeDirectory: /home/user01
loginShell: /bin/bash
l: Fake Town
mailLocalAddress: user01@msjackson.stankonia.com
mailRoutingAddress: user01@msjackson.stankonia.com
userPassword:: e1NTSEF9N1A5Zi85NS9OSkltVkdEY1dIK09hVHBVUFYxN2hCOFY=
shadowExpire: -1
shadowFlag: 0
shadowWarning: 7
shadowMin: 8
shadowMax: 999999
shadowLastChange: 10877
postalCode: 01234
o: MsJackson-Outkast-StankoniaInc
mobile: +33 (0)6 xx xx xx xx
homePhone: +33 (0)5 xx xx xx xx
postalAddress: 123 Fake St., Goleta, CA 93117
initials: GSSAPI

dn: cn=user01,ou=groups,dc=msjackson,dc=stankonia,dc=com
objectClass: top
objectClass: posixGroup
cn: user01
gidNumber: 4001
memberUid: user01
{code}

So if you wanted to differentiate which objects are users and groups, the LIC file section for users and groups may look like the following:

{code}
"groups":{

"base-dn":"ou=groups,dc=msjackson,dc=stankonia,dc=com",
"id-attribute":"cn",
"member-attribute":"memberUid",
"selection":{
"filter":"objectClass=posixGroup",
}

},


"users":{

"base-dn":"ou=people,dc=msjackson,dc=stankonia,dc=com",
"id-attribute":"uid",
"sasl-id-attribute":"uid",
"selection":{
"filter":"objectClass=inetOrgPerson",
}
{code}

So what this does is grab all the users and groups defined with these attributes in LDAP/AD.  What maps where groups and users end up regarding accounts *DEPENDS* upon the accounting-groups or groups-partition definitions.  So, typically, if someone has defined an _ou_ for Sales, users and groups are structured underneath that _ou_.  If a groups-partition has been defined, then the groups found in LDAP/AD that are defined in each account, will add all the groups to that account, and will look up each user that is a member of those groups and add them to the account.
fields.summary: LDAP/AD Integration:  Update Identity Mapping Explanation

comments.body:
[~hspencer], As discussed this afternoon, "3.4-PM" label is a product management internal label being used simply for organizing the issues in Jira. The label as such should mean nothing in general, and specifically should not denote the fix / release versions. (For those interested in how this is being used internally, in this case, product management is using this label simply to denote that tickets labeled with "3.4-PM" need attention between now and 3.4. It does not mean that these will get attention. It also does not mean that those that do not have this label will not get attention) 

In short, please don't worry about this label, and pass the issue along the normal Support -> Engineering channels that you use for consideration by Engineering (in 3.3 or 3.3.1 or 3.4 or beyond). Let me know if you have any questions. Thanks.

Added in pull request for this fix:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/documentation/pull/69
Looks like this was merged some time ago. Closing.
